title: Schema marked as reference schema document must conform
text: Any schema document with an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument MUST be a reference schema document.

title: Schema marked as extension schema document must conform
text: Any schema document with an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ExtensionSchemaDocument MUST be an extension schema document.

title: Schema is CTAS-conformant
post: The term conformant document is defined by [CTAS] Section 3.2, Conformance to this Specification. Note that this rule uses sch:report to provide a location that must be checked for conformance to an external standard, and does not itself provide any enforcement or checking of the actual rule.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:report test="true()">The document MUST be a conformant document as defined by the NIEM Conformance Targets Attribute Specification.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST be a conformant document as defined by the NIEM Conformance Targets Attribute Specification.

title: Document element has attribute ct:conformanceTargets
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.) or exists(@ct:conformanceTargets)]"> <sch:assert test="(. is nf:get-document-element(.)) = exists(@ct:conformanceTargets)" >The [document element] of the XML document, and only the [document element], MUST own an attribute {http://release.niem.gov/niem/conformanceTargets/3.0/}conformanceTargets.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The [document element] of the XML document, and only the [document element], MUST own an attribute {http://release.niem.gov/niem/conformanceTargets/3.0/}conformanceTargets.

title: Schema claims reference schema conformance target

schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:assert test="nf:has-effective-conformance-target-identifier(., xs:anyURI('http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument'))" >The document MUST have an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST have an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument.

title: Schema claims extension conformance target
post: This document defines the term effective conformance target identifier.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:assert test="nf:has-effective-conformance-target-identifier(., xs:anyURI('http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ExtensionSchemaDocument'))" >The document MUST have an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ExtensionSchemaDocument.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST have an effective conformance target identifier of http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ExtensionSchemaDocument.

title: Document is an XML document
post: The term XML document is defined by this document.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:report test="true()">The document MUST be an XML document.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST be an XML document.

title: Document uses XML namespaces properly
post: The terms namespace-well-formed and namespace-valid are normatively defined by [XML Namespaces] and [XML Namespaces Errata].
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:report test="true()">The document MUST be namespace-well-formed and namespace-valid.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST be namespace-well-formed and namespace-valid.

title: Document is a schema document
post: This document defines the term schema document.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:report test="true()">The document MUST be a schema document.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The document MUST be a schema document.

title: Document element is xs:schema
post: This document defines the term XML document.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="*[. is nf:get-document-element(.)]"> <sch:assert test="self::xs:schema" >The [document element] of the XML document MUST have the name xs:schema.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The [document element] of the XML document MUST have the name xs:schema.

title: Component name follows ISO 11179 Part 5 Annex A
post: The guidelines and examples of [ISO 11179-5] provide a simple, consistent syntax for data names that captures context and thereby imparts a reasonable degree of semantic precision.
text: A NIEM component name MUST be formed by applying the informative guidelines and examples detailed in Annex A of [ISO 11179-5], with exceptions as specified in this document.

title: No base type in the XML namespace
pre: Although the XML namespace is to be imported as if it is conformant, types from that namespace may not be the base type definition of any type.
post: The term base type definition has a normative definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@base)]"> <sch:assert test="namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@base, .)) != xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace')" >A schema component must not have a base type definition with a {target namespace} that is the XML namespace.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component must not have a base type definition with a {target namespace} that is the XML namespace.

title: No base type of xs:ID
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@base)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@base, .) != xs:QName('xs:ID')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:ID.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:ID.

title: No base type of xs:IDREF

title: No base type of xs:anyType
post: XML Schema has the concept of the ur-type, a type that is the root of all other types. This type is realized in schemas as xs:anyType.

text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:anyType.

title: No base type of xs:anySimpleType
post: XML Schema provides a restriction of the ur-type that contains only simple content. This provides a wildcard for arbitrary text. It is realized in XML Schema as xs:anySimpleType.

text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:anySimpleType.

title: No base type of xs:NOTATION
post: XML Schema notations allow the attachment of system and public identifiers on fields of data. The notation mechanism does not play a part in validation of instances and is not supported by NIEM.

text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:NOTATION.

title: No base type of xs:ENTITY

text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:ENTITY.

title: No base type of xs:ENTITIES
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[exists(@base)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@base, .) != xs:QName('xs:ENTITIES')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:ENTITIES.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}base with a value of xs:ENTITIES.

title: Simple type definition is top-level
post: NIEM does not support anonymous types in NIEM-conformant schemas. All XML Schema top-level types (children of the document element) are required by XML Schema to be named. By requiring NIEM type definitions to be top level, they are forced to be named and are globally reusable.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleType"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:schema)" >A simple type definition MUST be top-level.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A simple type definition MUST be top-level.

title: No simple type disallowed derivation
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleType"> <sch:assert test="empty(@final)" >An element xs:simpleType MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:simpleType MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.

title: Simple type has data definition
post: This document defines the term data definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleType"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in xs:annotation/xs:documentation[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >A simple type MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A simple type MUST have a data definition.

title: Enumeration has data definition
post: This document defines the term data definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:enumeration"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in xs:annotation/xs:documentation[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >An enumeration facet MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An enumeration facet MUST have a data definition.

title: Complex type definitions is top-level
post: Note that this implies that every xs:complexType element has a name attribute.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:schema)" >A complex type definition MUST be top-level.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type definition MUST be top-level.

title: Complex type has data definition
post: This document defines the term data definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in xs:annotation/xs:documentation[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >A complex type MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type MUST have a data definition.

title: No mixed content on complex type
post: Mixed content allows the mixing of data tags with text. Languages such as XHTML use this syntax for markup of text. NIEM-conformant schemas define XML that is for data exchange, not text markup. Mixed content creates complexity in processing, defining, and constraining content.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[exists(@mixed)]"> <sch:assert test="xs:boolean(@mixed) = false()" >A complex type definition MUST NOT have mixed content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type definition MUST NOT have mixed content.

title: No mixed content on complex content
post: See Rule 9-26, No mixed content on complex type (REF, EXT), above, for the rationale for this rule.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexContent[exists(@mixed)]"> <sch:assert test="xs:boolean(@mixed) = false()" >A complex type definition with complex content MUST NOT have mixed content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type definition with complex content MUST NOT have mixed content.

title: Complex type content is explicitly simple or complex
post: XML Schema provides shorthand to defining complex content of a complex type, which is to define the complex type with immediate children that specify elements, or other groups, and attributes. In the desire to normalize schema representation of types and to be explicit, NIEM forbids the use of that shorthand.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:assert test="exists(xs:simpleContent) or exists(xs:complexContent)" >An element xs:complexType MUST have a child element xs:simpleContent or xs:complexContent.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:complexType MUST have a child element xs:simpleContent or xs:complexContent.

title: Complex content uses extension
post: NIEM does not support the use of complex type restriction in reference schemas. The use of restriction in a reference schema would reduce the ability for that schema to be reused. Restriction may be used in extension schemas.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexContent"> <sch:assert test="exists(xs:extension)" >An element xs:complexContent MUST have a child xs:extension.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:complexContent MUST have a child xs:extension.

section.name: 9.1.3.2.1. Base type of complex type with complex content has complex content

title: Base type of complex type with complex content must have complex content
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType/xs:complexContent/xs:*[ (self::xs:extension or self::xs:restriction) and (some $base-qname in resolve-QName(@base, .) satisfies namespace-uri-from-QName($base-qname) = nf:get-target-namespace(.))]"> <sch:assert test="some $base-type in nf:resolve-type(., resolve-QName(@base, .)) satisfies empty($base-type/self::xs:complexType/xs:simpleContent)" >The base type of complex type that has complex content MUST be a complex type with complex content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The base type of complex type that has complex content MUST be a complex type with complex content.

section.name: 9.1.3.2.1. Base type of complex type with complex content has complex content

title: Base type of complex type with complex content must have complex content
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[ nf:has-effective-conformance-target-identifier(., xs:anyURI('http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ReferenceSchemaDocument')) or nf:has-effective-conformance-target-identifier(., xs:anyURI('http://reference.niem.gov/niem/specification/naming-and-design-rules/3.0/#ExtensionSchemaDocument')) ]/xs:complexContent"> <sch:assert test="some $derivation in xs:*[self::xs:extension or self::xs:restriction], $base-qname in resolve-QName($derivation/@base, $derivation), $base-type in nf:resolve-type($derivation, $base-qname) satisfies empty($base-type/self::xs:complexType/xs:simpleContent)" >The base type of complex type that has complex content MUST have complex content.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The base type of complex type that has complex content MUST have complex content.

title: Simple content uses extension
post: This rule ensures that the definition of a complex type with simple content will use XML Schema extension. This allows for the above cases while disallowing more complicated syntactic options available in XML Schema. The above rule allows for use of xs:restriction within xs:simpleContent in extension schemas.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:simpleContent"> <sch:assert test="exists(xs:extension)" >A complex type definition with simple content schema component MUST have a derivation method of extension.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type definition with simple content schema component MUST have a derivation method of extension.

title: No complex type disallowed substitutions
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:assert test="empty(@block)" >An element xs:complexType MUST NOT have an attribute {}block.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:complexType MUST NOT have an attribute {}block.

title: No complex type disallowed derivation
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType"> <sch:assert test="empty(@final)" >An element xs:complexType MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:complexType MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.

title: Element declaration is top-level
post: All schema components defined by NIEM-conformant schemas must be named, accessible from outside the defining schema, and reusable across schemas. Local element declarations provide named elements that are not reusable outside the context in which they are defined.Requiring named NIEM elements to be top level ensures that they are globally reusable.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:schema)" >An element declaration MUST be top-level.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration MUST be top-level.

title: Element declaration has data definition
post: This document defines the term data definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in xs:annotation/xs:documentation[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >An element declaration MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration MUST have a data definition.

title: Untyped element is abstract
post: Untyped element declarations act as wildcards that may carry arbitrary data. By declaring such types abstract, NIEM allows the creation of type independent semantics without allowing arbitrary content to appear in XML instances.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema/xs:element[empty(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@abstract) and xs:boolean(@abstract) = true()" >A top-level element declaration that does not set the {type definition} property via the attribute "type" MUST have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A top-level element declaration that does not set the {type definition} property via the attribute "type" MUST have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".

title: Element of type xs:anySimpleType is abstract
pre: The type xs:anySimpleType does not have any concrete semantics; The use of xs:anySimpleType is limited to the case where an abstract element is of type xs:anySimpleType, to act as a base for concrete implementations of the element.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@type) and resolve-QName(@type, .) = xs:QName('xs:anySimpleType')]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@abstract) and xs:boolean(@abstract) = true()" >An element declaration that has a type xs:anySimpleType MUST have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration that has a type xs:anySimpleType MUST have the {abstract} property with a value of "true".

title: Element type not in the XML Schema namespace
post: The prohibition of element types having the XML Schema namespace subsumes a prohibition of the type xs:anyType.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="for $type-qname in resolve-QName(@type, .) return $type-qname = xs:QName('xs:anySimpleType') or namespace-uri-from-QName($type-qname) != xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema')" >An element type that is not xs:anySimpleType MUST NOT have a namespace name <namespace-uri-for-prefix>xs</namespace-uri-for-prefix>.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element type that is not xs:anySimpleType MUST NOT have a namespace name

title: Element type not in the XML namespace
pre: The XML namespace may be imported into an conformant schema document as if it were conformant. This specification does not enable a reference to any types that may be defined by any implementation of a schema for that namespace.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@type, .)) != 'http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace'" >An element type MUST NOT have a namespace name that is in the XML namespace.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element type MUST NOT have a namespace name that is in the XML namespace.

title: Element type is not simple type
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[@type]"> <sch:assert test="every $type-qname in resolve-QName(@type, .), $type-ns in namespace-uri-from-QName($type-qname), $type-local-name in local-name-from-QName($type-qname) satisfies ( $type-qname = xs:QName('xs:anySimpleType') or (($type-ns = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or exists(nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[ xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $type-ns and empty(@appinfo:externalImportIndicator)])) and not(ends-with($type-local-name, 'SimpleType'))))" >An element type that is not xs:anySimpleType MUST NOT be a simple type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element type that is not xs:anySimpleType MUST NOT be a simple type.

title: No element disallowed substitutions
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element"> <sch:assert test="empty(@block)" >An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}block.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}block.

title: No element disallowed derivation
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element"> <sch:assert test="empty(@final)" >An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}final.

title: No element default value
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element"> <sch:assert test="empty(@default)" >An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}default.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}default.

title: No element fixed value
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element"> <sch:assert test="empty(@fixed)" >An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}fixed.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:element MUST NOT have an attribute {}fixed.

title: Element declaration is nillable
pre: A developer may constrain the use of nil in an instance by setting nillable to false in subset schemas, or by use of non-XML Schema mechanisms, such as Schematron.
post: This document defines the term element declaration.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[@name and (empty(@abstract) or xs:boolean(@abstract) = false())]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@nillable) and xs:boolean(@nillable) = true()" >An element declaration MUST have the {nillable} property with a value of true.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element declaration MUST have the {nillable} property with a value of true.

title: Attribute declaration is top-level
post: All schema components defined by NIEM-conformant schemas are named, accessible from outside the defining schema, and reusable across schemas. Local attribute declarations provide named attributes that are not reusable outside the context in which they are defined. Requiring named NIEM attributes to be top level ensures that they are globally reusable.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:schema)" >An attribute declaration MUST be top-level.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An attribute declaration MUST be top-level.

title: Attribute declaration has data definition
post: This document defines the term data definition.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in xs:annotation/xs:documentation[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >An attribute declaration MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An attribute declaration MUST have a data definition.

title: Attribute declaration has type
post: Untyped XML Schema attributes allow arbitrary content, with no semantics. Attributes must have a type so that specific syntax and semantics will be provided.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@name)]"> <sch:assert test="exists(@type)" >A top-level attribute declaration MUST have a type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A top-level attribute declaration MUST have a type.

title: No attribute type of xs:ID
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:ID')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ID.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ID.

title: No attribute type of xs:IDREF
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:IDREF')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:IDREF.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:IDREF.

title: No attribute type of xs:IDREFS
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:IDREFS')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:IDREFS.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:IDREFS.

title: No attribute type of xs:ENTITY
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:ENTITY')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ENTITY.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ENTITY.

title: No attribute type of xs:ENTITIES
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:ENTITIES')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ENTITIES.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:ENTITIES.

title: No attribute type of xs:anySimpleType
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute[exists(@type)]"> <sch:assert test="resolve-QName(@type, .) != xs:QName('xs:anySimpleType')" >A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:anySimpleType.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A schema component MUST NOT have an attribute {}type with a value of xs:anySimpleType.

title: No attribute default values
post: This rule helps to ensure that schema processing does not alter processed data, as described in Section 8.4, Ensure schema processing does not alter processed data, above.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute"> <sch:assert test="empty(@default)" >An element xs:attribute MUST NOT have an attribute {}default.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:attribute MUST NOT have an attribute {}default.

title: No attribute fixed values
post: This rule helps to ensure that schema processing does not alter processed data, as described in Section 8.4, Ensure schema processing does not alter processed data, above. The use of the fixed attribute may result in alteration of the post-schema-validation infoset, like the use of default does. This behavior is described by [XML Schema Structures] Section 3.2.1, The Attribute Declaration Schema Component.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attribute"> <sch:assert test="empty(@fixed)" >An element xs:attribute MUST NOT have an attribute {}fixed.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:attribute MUST NOT have an attribute {}fixed.

title: No use of element xs:notation
post: See Rule 9-7, No base type of xs:NOTATION (REF, EXT), above, for comments about the use of notations.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:notation"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:notation.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:notation.

title: Model group does not affect meaning
text: The use of model groups xs:all, xs:sequence, and xs:choice MUST NOT define the semantics of an instance. The meaning of an element occurrance within an element occurrence MUST be identical, regardless of the model group used to define a schema component.

title: No xs:all
post: The element xs:all provides a set of particles (e.g., elements) that may be included in an instance, in no particular order. This compositor does not support a variety of cardinalities, has shown to be confusing in practice, and has functionality that overlaps with NIEM’s use of substitution groups. Use of substitution groups is the preferred method in NIEM schemas for obtaining flexible content models.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:all"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:all</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:all

title: xs:sequence must be child of xs:extension
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:sequence"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:extension)" >An element xs:sequence MUST be a child of element xs:extension.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:sequence MUST be a child of element xs:extension.

title: xs:sequence must be child of xs:extension or xs:restriction
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:sequence"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:extension) or exists(parent::xs:restriction)" >An element xs:sequence MUST be a child of element xs:extension or xs:restriction.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:sequence MUST be a child of element xs:extension or xs:restriction.

title: No xs:choice
post: The element xs:choice provides an exclusive set of particles, one of which may appear in an instance. This can greatly complicate processing and may be difficult to comprehend, satisfy, and reuse.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:choice"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:choice</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:choice

title: xs:choice must be child of xs:sequence
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:choice"> <sch:assert test="exists(parent::xs:sequence)" >An element xs:choice MUST be a child of element xs:sequence.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:choice MUST be a child of element xs:sequence.

title: Sequence has minimum cardinality 1
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:sequence"> <sch:assert test="empty(@minOccurs) or xs:integer(@minOccurs) = 1" >An element xs:sequence MUST either not have the attribute {}minOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:sequence MUST either not have the attribute {}minOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.

title: Sequence has maximum cardinality 1
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:sequence"> <sch:assert test="empty(@maxOccurs) or (@maxOccurs instance of xs:integer and 1 = xs:integer(@maxOccurs))" >An element xs:sequence MUST either not have the attribute {}maxOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:sequence MUST either not have the attribute {}maxOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.

title: Choice has minimum cardinality 1
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:choice"> <sch:assert test="empty(@minOccurs) or 1 = xs:integer(@minOccurs)" >An element xs:choice MUST either not have the attribute {}minOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:choice MUST either not have the attribute {}minOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.

title: Choice has maximum cardinality 1
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:choice"> <sch:assert test="empty(@maxOccurs) or (@maxOccurs instance of xs:integer and 1 = xs:integer(@maxOccurs))" >An element xs:choice MUST either not have the attribute {}maxOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:choice MUST either not have the attribute {}maxOccurs, or that attribute MUST have a value of 1.

title: No use of xs:any
post: The xs:any particle (see Model Group Restrictions for an informative definition of particle) provides a wildcard that may carry arbitrary content. The particle xs:any may appear within an extension schema document.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:any"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:any.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:any.

title: No use of xs:anyAttribute
post: The xs:anyAttribute element provides a wildcard, where arbitrary attributes may appear.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:anyAttribute"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:anyAttribute.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:anyAttribute.

title: No use of xs:unique
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:unique"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:unique.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:unique.

title: No use of xs:key
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:key"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:key.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:key.

title: No use of xs:keyref
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:keyref"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:keyref.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:keyref.

title: No use of xs:group
post: NIEM does not allow groups of elements to be named other than as named complex types. A group in XML Schema creates a named entity that may be included in multiple types, and which consists of a sequence of or choice between element particles. NIEM has not developed a semantic model for these components, and they are not integrated into NIEM’s design.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:group"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:group.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:group.

title: No definition of attribute groups
pre: Per Rule 11-24, Schema uses only known attribute groups (REF, EXT), below, the only attribute groups used in NIEM-conformant schemas are structures:SimpleObjectAttributeGroup and attribute groups defined by the IC-ISM and IC-NTK schemas. Therefore, NIEM-conformant schemas do not define additional attribute groups.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:attributeGroup[@name]"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain an attribute group definition schema component.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain an attribute group definition schema component.

title: Comment is not recommended
pre: Note that this rule is written with a context that is not as precise as it could be. Its context is the parent node of the comment node, in order to avoid error messages when executed with common Schematron implementations.
post: Since XML comments are not associated with any specific XML Schema construct, there is no standard way to interpret comments. XML Schema annotations should be preferred for meaningful information about components. NIEM specifically defines how information should be encapsulated in NIEM-conformant schemas via xs:annotation elements.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="node()[comment()]"> <sch:report test="true()" >An XML Comment is not an XML Schema annotation component; an XML comment SHOULD NOT appear in the schema.</sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An XML Comment is not an XML Schema annotation component; an XML comment SHOULD NOT appear in the schema.

title: Documentation element has no element children
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:documentation/node()"> <sch:assert test="self::text() or self::comment()" >A child of element xs:documentation MUST be text or an XML comment.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A child of element xs:documentation MUST be text or an XML comment.

title: xs:appinfo children are comments, elements, or whitespace
post: Application information elements are intended for automatic processing; the meaning of an appinfo annotation is provided via elements.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:appinfo/node()"> <sch:assert test="self::comment() or self::element() or self::text()[string-length(normalize-space(.)) = 0]" >A child of element xs:appinfo MUST be an element, a comment, or whitespace text.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A child of element xs:appinfo MUST be an element, a comment, or whitespace text.

title: Appinfo child elements have namespaces
post: The XML namespaces specification includes the concept of content not in a namespace. Use of elements without namespaces can lead to conflicting data definitions, and makes it difficult to identify relevant data definitions.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:appinfo/*"> <sch:assert test="namespace-uri() != xs:anyURI('')" >An element that is a child of xs:appinfo MUST have a namespace name.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element that is a child of xs:appinfo MUST have a namespace name.

title: Appinfo descendants are not XML Schema elements
post: NIEM-conformant schemas are designed to be very easily processed. Although uses of XML Schema elements as content of xs:appinfo elements could be contrived, it is not current practice and complicates the processing of XML elements by their namespaces and names. Forbidding the use of XML Schema elements outside valid uses of schema simplifies such processing.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:appinfo//xs:*"> <sch:assert test="false()" >An element with a namespace name of xs: MUST NOT have an ancestor element xs:appinfo.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element with a namespace name of xs: MUST NOT have an ancestor element xs:appinfo.

title: Schema has data definition
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema"> <sch:assert test="some $definition in (xs:annotation/xs:documentation)[1] satisfies string-length(normalize-space(string($definition))) > 0" >An element xs:schema MUST have a data definition.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:schema MUST have a data definition.

title: Schema document defines target namespace
post: Schemas without defined namespaces provide definitions that are ambiguous, in that they are not universally identifiable.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema"> <sch:assert test="exists(@targetNamespace)" >The schema MUST define a target namespace.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST define a target namespace.

title: Target namespace is absolute URI
post: Absolute URIs are the only universally meaningful URIs. URIs include both URLs and URNs. Finding the target namespace using standard XML Base technology is complicated and not specified by XML Schema. Relative URIs are not universally identifiable, as they are context-specific. <absolute-URI> is a grammar production defined by [RFC 3986] Section 4.3, Absolute URI.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema[exists(@targetNamespace)]"> <sch:report test="true()" ><![CDATA[The value of the attribute targetNamespace MUST match the production <absolute-URI> as defined by RFC 3986.]]></sch:report> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The value of the attribute targetNamespace MUST match the production <absolute-URI> as defined by RFC 3986.

title: Schema has version
pre: An author of an application schema or exchange may use the version attribute for these purposes within their schemas.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema"> <sch:assert test="some $version in @version satisfies string-length(normalize-space(@version)) > 0" >An element xs:schema MUST have an attribute {}version that MUST NOT be empty.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:schema MUST have an attribute {}version that MUST NOT be empty.

title: No disallowed substitutions
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema"> <sch:assert test="empty(@blockDefault)" >An element xs:schema MUST NOT have an attribute {}blockDefault.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:schema MUST NOT have an attribute {}blockDefault.

title: No disallowed derivations
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:schema"> <sch:assert test="empty(@finalDefault)" >An element xs:schema MUST NOT have an attribute {}finalDefault.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:schema MUST NOT have an attribute {}finalDefault.

title: No use of xs:redefine
post: The xs:redefine element allows an XML Schema document to restrict and extend components from a namespace, in a separate schema document from the one that initially defined that namespace. Such redefinition introduces duplication of definitions, allowing multiple definitions to exist for components from a single namespace. This violates [Principle 9], above, that a single reference schema defines a NIEM-conformant namespace.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:redefine"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:redefine.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:redefine.

title: No use of xs:include
post: Element xs:include brings schemas defined in separate files into the current namespace. It breaks a namespace up into arbitrary partial schemas, which needlessly complicates the schema structure, making it harder to reuse and process, and also increases the likelihood of conflicting definitions.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:include"> <sch:assert test="false()" >The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:include.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The schema MUST NOT contain the element xs:include.

title: xs:import must have namespace
post: An import that does not specify a namespace is enabling references to non-namespaced components. NIEM requires that all components have a defined namespace. It is important that the namespace declared by a schema be universally defined and unambiguous.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:import"> <sch:assert test="exists(@namespace)" >An element xs:import MUST have an attribute {}namespace.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An element xs:import MUST have an attribute {}namespace.

title: XML Schema document set must be complete
pre: An XML Schema document set defines an XML Schema that may be used to validate an XML document. This rule ensures that a schema document set under consideration contains definitions for everything that it references; it has everything necessary to do a complete validation of XML documents, without any unresolved references. Note that some tools may allow validation of documents using partial schemas, when components that are not present are not exercised by the XML document under validation. Such a schema does not meet qualify as a conformant schema document set.
text: The schema document set must constitute a complete XML Schema; it must contain the definition of every schema component referenced by any component defined by the schema set.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespace referenced by attribute type is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@type]"> <sch:assert test="every $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@type, .)) satisfies ( $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or $namespace = xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema') or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace])" >The namespace of a type referenced by @type MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a type referenced by @type MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespace referenced by attribute base is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@base]"> <sch:assert test="every $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@base, .)) satisfies ( $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or $namespace = xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema') or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace])" >The namespace of a type referenced by @base MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a type referenced by @base MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespace referenced by attribute itemType is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@itemType]"> <sch:assert test="every $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@itemType, .)) satisfies ( $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or $namespace = xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema') or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace])" >The namespace of a type referenced by @itemType MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a type referenced by @itemType MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespaces referenced by attribute memberTypes is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@memberTypes]"> <sch:assert test="every $type in tokenize(normalize-space(@memberTypes), ' '), $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName($type, .)) satisfies ( $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or $namespace = xs:anyURI('http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema') or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace])" >The namespace of a type referenced by @memberTypes MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a type referenced by @memberTypes MUST be the target namespace, the XML Schema namespace, or be imported.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespace referenced by attribute ref is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@ref]"> <sch:assert test="every $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@ref, .)) satisfies $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace]" >The namespace of a component referenced by @ref MUST be the target namespace or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a component referenced by @ref MUST be the target namespace or be imported.

section.name: 9.8.1. Namespaces for referenced components are imported

title: Namespace referenced by attribute substitutionGroup is imported
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:*[@substitutionGroup]"> <sch:assert test="every $namespace in namespace-uri-from-QName(resolve-QName(@substitutionGroup, .)) satisfies $namespace = nf:get-target-namespace(.) or nf:get-document-element(.)/xs:import[xs:anyURI(@namespace) = $namespace]" >The namespace of a component referenced by @substitutionGroup MUST be the target namespace or be imported.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The namespace of a component referenced by @substitutionGroup MUST be the target namespace or be imported.

title: Complex type has a category
post: This rule establishes the categories of NIEM complex types. It is a limited set, and each category has distinct semantics, as described by following sections.
text: Within the schema, a complex type definition MUST be one of the following:

title: Object type with complex content is derived from object type
post: A base type definition with a {target namespace} that is the XML namespace is prohibited by Rule 9-1, No base type in the XML namespace (REF, EXT), above. A base type definition with a {target namespace} that is not imported as conformant is prohibited by Rule 11-3, Base type definition defined by conformant schema (REF, EXT), below.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[exists(xs:complexContent) and not(ends-with(@name, 'AssociationType') or ends-with(@name, 'MetadataType') or ends-with(@name, 'AugmentationType'))]"> <sch:assert test=" every $derivation-method in (xs:complexContent/xs:extension, xs:complexContent/xs:restriction), $base in $derivation-method/@base, $base-qname in resolve-QName($base, $derivation-method), $base-local-name in local-name-from-QName($base-qname) satisfies ( $base-qname = xs:QName('structures:ObjectType') or not(ends-with($base-local-name, 'AssociationType') or ends-with($base-local-name, 'MetadataType') or ends-with($base-local-name, 'AugmentationType')))" >An object type with complex content MUST be derived from structures:ObjectType or from another object type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: An object type with complex content MUST be derived from structures:ObjectType or from another object type.

title: RoleOf element type is an object type
post: Note that by Rule 11-14, Element type is from conformant namespace (REF, EXT), below, the element’s type must be from a conformant namespace.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:element[@name[starts-with(., 'RoleOf')]]"> <sch:assert test="every $type in @type, $type-local-name in local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName($type, .)) satisfies not(ends-with($type-local-name, 'AssociationType') or ends-with($type-local-name, 'MetadataType') or ends-with($type-local-name, 'AugmentationType'))" >The type definition of a RoleOf element MUST be an object type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: The type definition of a RoleOf element MUST be an object type.

title: Only object type has RoleOf element
post: Note that RoleOf element and object type are defined terms.
schematron: <sch:pattern> <sch:rule context="xs:complexType[ empty(@appinfo:externalAdapterTypeIndicator) and exists(descendant::xs:element[ exists(@ref[ starts-with(local-name-from-QName(resolve-QName(., ..)), 'RoleOf')])])]"> <sch:assert test="not(ends-with(@name, 'AssociationType') or ends-with(@name, 'MetadataType') or ends-with(@name, 'AugmentationType'))" >A complex type that includes a RoleOf element in its content model MUST be an object type.</sch:assert> </sch:rule> </sch:pattern>
text: A complex type that includes a RoleOf element in its content model MUST be an object type.

title: RoleOf elements indicate the base types of a role type
text: An element declaration that has a local name that begins with the string RoleOf MUST represent a base type, of which the containing element instance represents a role.

title: External attribute use not an ID
pre: NIEM schemas use structures:id to enable references between components. Each NIEM-defined complex type must incorporate a definition for structures:id. [XML] Section 3.3.1, Attribute Types entails that a complex type may have no more than one ID attribute. This means that an external attribute use must not be an ID attribute.

title: Name of code type ends in CodeType
post: Using the qualifier Code (e.g. CodeType, CodeSimpleType) immediately identifies a type as representing a fixed list of codes. Codes may also have responsible authorities behind them who provide concrete semantic bindings for the code values.

title: Proxy type has designated structure
